author: Natalie Hayes
title: Lincolnwood looks for answers to contentious flag display at Oakton's Justice Summit Lincolnwood Review
text:
The village of Lincolnwood has yet to make a conclusive decision about the future of a flag display that turned controversial last year when it became apparent that strong religious and political divisions exist in one of the North Shore area's most diverse communities.
While next year's plans for the village's annual Diversity Month and flag display are still being decided, the village is starting to explore ways to promote more inclusivity among the diverse number of nationalities represented in Lincolnwood's population.
The Village Board will make a final decision about the future of the display before next summer, but the Human Relations Commission is being tasked with coming up with new, possibly less-controversial suggestions that could replace the flags, according to Rebecca Kohn, chair of the commission.
"Some people strongly supported it, and some hated it, but in the end it's impossible to make everyone happy," Kohn said.
Kohn was one of three Lincolnwood representatives to join Mayor Turry at the Justice Summit, a conference at Oakton Community College on Sunday that offered resources to help North Shore-area communities develop better practices for embracing diversity.
About 85 people representing more than 15 communities in suburban Chicago attended the conference, which included speeches from State Rep. Robyn Gabel; Michael Anthony, the chief diversity officer at Oakton Community College; and Maria Hadden, project manager for the Participatory Budgeting Project.

(Angie Leventis Lourgos) Some of the ideas posed during the conference were to hold casual coffee sessions to help residents feel more open to sharing their ideas with village officials and to consider the "Participatory Budgeting Project," a budgeting process used in some Wards in Chicago that gives citizens a direct voice in allocating public money.
Sponsored by Winnetka-based Open Communities—an organization that advocates for social injustice and fair housing opportunities, the goal of the conference was to provide North Shore communities with ideas for embracing diversity.
Participatory budgeting allows citizens to decide where and how to spend public funds—allowing residents to get a bigger stake in local spending by voting on which projects public money should be spent on.
At the end of the conference, communities were divided into breakout sessions to start planning the details of their campaigns for embracing diversity.
The consensus for Skokie and Lincolnwood, according to Gayle Schecter, executive director for Open Communities, was to encourage leaders to get to know the diverse groups of people who live in the communities they represent.

(Natalie Hayes) "The bottom line for Lincolnwood and Skokie is that they're diverse," Schecter said. "People don't always know each other, so their prejudices are built on ignorance and a lack of opportunities to meet each other."
Turry said he and Kohn would bring some ideas from the Justice Summit back to the Human Relations Commission to help build a multifaceted program for addressing diversity in the community.
Lincolnwood's long-running tradition of displaying a row of about 60 flags along Lincoln Avenue each August in honor of the village's "Diversity Month" came under fire last year when some residents took offense to the presence of the Palestinian flag.
Relations between Palestine and Israel were at a boiling point in late 2014, and the village defended the right of the Palestinian flag to continue flying after a handful of residents sounded off against it being included in the display during a public meeting attended by hundreds of residents.
The August 2014 meeting grew so heated at one point that accusations of discrimination and even terrorism flew between angry community members, prompting Lincolnwood Mayor Jerry Turry to threaten to throw people out of village hall.
The flag display was absent from Lincoln Avenue this past August due to a public works project, but Lincolnwood officials have not said whether the tradition would continue again next year or whether new activities to celebrate the community's diversity would begin.
Natalie Hayes is a freelance reporter for Pioneer Press.
